title: 107_hr3176
content: The Act titled "Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act" establishes protocols for national responses to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals, including intentional releases. The Act defines hazardous agents as dangerous biological agents and chemicals, and the Secretary must consult with states in this process. The Act requires the Secretary to develop a list of dangerous chemicals known to cause serious health effects within 45 days of enactment. The Act mandates the development of protocols for hazardous agents with specific provisions for each agent, prioritizing them within 45 days of enactment. The Secretary must promptly develop protocols for hazardous agents, starting with the highest priority agent within 45 days. The protocols must ensure uniform application in public health emergencies and coordinate with emergency response personnel. Medically appropriate information must be provided promptly. The Secretary must develop protocols for hazardous agents promptly, ensuring uniform application in public health emergencies. This includes providing medically appropriate information, testing and treating affected individuals, decontaminating sites, and addressing accidental or intentional releases. The protocols will be periodically reviewed and revised as needed. Development exemptions may apply if existing protocols meet requirements. The Secretary must develop protocols for hazardous agents promptly, ensuring uniform application in public health emergencies. Development exemptions may be granted for hazardous agents. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2002 through 2006.
